items.description: Upper Bristol Avon area
items.message:
Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible.
River levels are currently falling but remain high.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Bristol Avon, Tetbury Avon, Sherston Avon, Dauntsey Brook, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around low lying areas in Tetbury, Badminton, Brook End at Luckington, Corsham, Lacock and the road at Reybridge. 
Tomorrow is forecast to be mainly dry and river levels are expected to continue falling.
We are closely monitoring the situation and no Flood Warnings are expected in this Flood Alert Area.
Please monitor local water levels and weather conditions and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.
Refer to local authority website for road closures.
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 23/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Trent from Cromwell Weir to Gainsborough
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River and high tide levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.  
We continue to monitor the situation.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses.  To check the status of road closures online, please visit the One Network live map.

items.description: Lower River Soar in Leicestershire
items.message:
River levels are high but steady at the Pillings Lock river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Slash Lane at Sileby and the Mountsorrel to Sileby road.   
No further rainfall is forecast.  We expect river levels to remain high. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
To check the status of road closures online, please visit the One Network live map.
This message will be updated by 09:00 tomorrow morning, 23/10/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Cherwell from Lower Heyford down to and including Oxford

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Cherwell, Woodeaton Brook, Bayswater Brook, Marston Brook, Peasmoor Brook

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. 
River levels are high but stable on the lower River Cherwell. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue today, 23/10/24  , especially in the Heyford and Thrupp areas. 
The forecast today is to remain largely dry. We expect river levels to remain high for the next few days. River levels remain sensitive to rainfall.
We are monitoring the situation.  Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 24/10/24 or as the situation changes.

items.message:
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.

Weather conditions are expected to remain largely dry for the next few days, and no further flooding is expected.

We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.

Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.description: Hundred Foot Washes in Cambridgeshire and Norfolk

floodArea.riverOrSea: Old Bedford River, New Bedford River, Hundred Foot Drain, River Delph

items.message: River levels are now returning to normal. The forecast is for no significant rainfall for the next few days. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely and reissue flood warnings and alerts when necessary.

items.description: Lower River Colne and Frays River

floodArea.county: Buckinghamshire, Greater London, Hertfordshire, Hillingdon, Slough, Surrey, Windsor and Maidenhead

items.message:
River levels are high on the Lower River Colne and Frays River today, Tuesday 22nd October.

No property flooding is expected, but flooding may continue to affect low lying land and roads, particularly in the Thorney Mill Road and Cricketfield Road areas, which may impact Riverside Mobile Home Park.

It will be mainly dry overnight and tomorrow, Wednesday 23rd October. River levels are expected to fall slowly over the next few days on the Lower Colne at our Staines Moor river gauge. 

We are continuing to monitor rainfall and river levels and will remove this alert when the risk has reduced.

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, and monitor local water levels and weather conditions.

This message will be updated by 6pm on Wednesday 23rd October, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tern and Perry catchments
items.message:
River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Tern - Walcot and Rodington river gauges following recent heavy rainfall. Flooding continues. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Wolverley to Newport. Other locations that may be affected include Market Drayton, Wem and Rodington.     

No further significant rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours.  River levels are falling but could remain high for several days. We are closely monitoring the situation.    

Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.    

This message will be updated by 10am tomorrow, 24/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Chertsey Bourne

floodArea.county: Bracknell Forest, Surrey, Windsor and Maidenhead

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels remain high today (23/10/2024) but steady on the Chertsey Bourne following recent persistent rainfall. Flooding of low lying land and roads is therefore expected to continue, especially in the Free Prae Road area of Chertsey. 

Today is forecast to be a mostly dry day with the possibility of light rain showers. River levels are forecast to slowly fall. We are monitoring the situation. Our staff are checking and clearing trash screens. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 24/10/24, or as the situation changes.

The forecast today is to remain largely dry. We expect river levels to remain high for the next few days. River levels remain sensitive to rainfall.

items.description: Lower Frome and tributaries
items.message:
Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible, property flooding is not expected.
Flooding is possible from 3PM on 22/10/2024.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Lower Dorset Frome, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Dorchester and Wareham.
No further rainfall is forecast overnight or tomorrow.
We are closely monitoring the situation 
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses.
Please do not drive through floodwater as bow waves may affect adjacent properties.
Stay away from floodwater - it contains hidden dangers such as open manhole covers, sewage and chemicals.
This message will be updated by 3:00 PM on 23/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Lugg south of Leominster
items.message:
River levels remain high but steady at the Lugwardine river gauge following recent heavy rainfall. Levels have now fallen below flood risk threshold at the Butts Bridge and Ford Bridge river gauges. Flooding continues. We expect flooding to affect Low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Lugg south of Leominster from Stoke Prior to Mordiford. Other locations that may be affected include Bodenham, Lugwardine and Hampton Bishop.    

No further significant rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours. River levels have peaked but will remain high for several days.   

We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.    

This message will be updated by 10am tomorrow, 24/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely from now, 4pm Tuesday 22nd October, into tomorrow. Water levels are expected to continue to rise gradually over the next few hours. This is due to a natural tide locking effect, and tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth is currently restricting the normal drainage of the Broads river system out to sea at low tide. We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry Road in Horning. The current series of high spring tides has now reached its peak, and falling away, however we are still,  at present, seeing a steady rise in river levels. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 9am tomorrow, Wednesday 23rd October.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message:
The River Yeo level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is 8.05 m and falling slowly. The drain level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is 7.36 m and dropping in response to pumping activities. 

Flooding will affect the road from Langport to Muchelney if this drain level exceeds 7.3m, the road from Muchelney to Long Load above 7.86m, the road from Muchelney to Thorney above 7.93m and the road from Muchelney to Draycott, Law Lane, above 8.8m. Property flooding is possible above 8.35m. 

Be aware the Langport to Muchelney road is closed. Please refer to www.somerset.gov.uk/roads-travel-and-parking/emergency-road-closure-gates for more information.

Weather conditions are forecast to remain largely dry for the next few days.

We are pumping at Huish Episcopi and Westover pumping stations, and are using the Parrett relief channel to reduce river levels. We are closely monitoring the situation and staff are continually checking the condition of flood banks, spillways and weed screens.

This message will be updated by 2 PM on 23/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Mid Bristol Avon area

floodArea.county: Bath and North East Somerset, Wiltshire

items.message:
Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible.
River levels are currently falling but remain high on the River Avon.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Bristol Avon, Semington Brook, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around low lying land and roads between Melksham and Bathford. The flood gates at Holt Road may be closed.
tomorrow is expected to be mainly dry and the river levels are expected to continue falling.
We are closely monitoring the situation and are not expecting to issue any Flood Warnings in this Flood Alert area.
Please monitor local water levels and weather conditions and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.
Refer to local authority website for road closures.
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 23/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Severn in Gloucestershire
items.message:
River levels remain high at the Haw Bridge river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall and high spring tides. Consequently, flooding is expected to continue. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Severn from Tewkesbury to Gloucester. Locations that may be affected include Apperley, Maisemore and Hempsted, and Severn Ham, Tewkesbury.

Peaks:- Mythe 4.62m Sunday evening, 20/10/2024, Haw Bridge 4.99m Sunday evening, 20/10/2024, and Sandhurst 3.95m Sunday evening 20/10/2024.

No further significant rainfall is forecast. River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk.

We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are liaising with emergency services and Local Authorities. Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

This message will be updated by 10am on Thursday 24/10/2024, or if the situation changes.

items.description: River Avon in Worcestershire
items.message:

We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent the River Avon from Abbotts Salford to Tewkesbury. Other locations that may be affected include Offenham, Evesham, Twyning and the Eckington Road.

No further significant rainfall is forecast. River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. 

This message will be updated by 9am on Thursday 24/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower Stour and tributaries

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council, Hampshire

items.message:
Rising river levels this morning may lead to flooding.
Flooding is possible from 12:00 noon on 22/10/2024.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Lower Dorset Stour, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Wimborne and Christchurch.
Further flooding is possible this afternoon as river levels are expected to remain high due to recent rainfall.
We are closely monitoring the situation 
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses.
Never drive through flood water,  just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car.
Stay away from floodwater - it contains hidden dangers such as open manhole covers, sewage and chemicals.
This message will be updated by 3:00 PM on 23/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Melverley.    

We expect river levels to remain high until Wednesday, 23/10/24.  

No further significant rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours.   

We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

items.description: River Thames at Trowlock Island
Tidal River Crane

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames

items.message: There is no longer a threat of flooding. The tide levels are now reducing from high spring tides towards neap tides later this week. The next high tide at Richmond at 6.30pm today, Tuesday 22nd October, is predicted to be 4.57m AOD and then 4.12m AOD at 6.45am tomorrow morning.  We expect the Crane Tidal Gates to close against the high tide. We will continue to monitor river and tide levels.

items.description: Severn estuary from Gloucester to Sharpness
items.message:
A flood alert has been issued as a series of high tides are expected over the next few days. Flooding may affect low lying land and roads adjacent the Severn Estuary from Sandhurst to Chepstow and Sharpness. Locations that may be affected include areas river side of defences where defences are present, including Lydney Harbour. Low lying land at Purton on the east bank may also be impacted. High tides may also affect watercourses draining into the Severn Estuary.  

Predicted peaks: Sandhurst 3.2m to 3.4m at 02:15 tomorrow 23/10/2024. Gloucester has now dropped below flood alert levels. 

Tidal levels are now reducing and are expected to continue to fall over the course of the week. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences. Please avoid contact with flood water.  

This message will be updated by 12pm midday on Wednesday 23/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Sow and River Penk

floodArea.riverOrSea: Sandyford Brook, Ridings Brook, Saredon Brook

items.description: Lower Tone and Parrett Moors
items.message:
The River Tone level at Currymoor pumping station is 7.26 m and falling steadily. Water will enter Currymoor reservoir via Hookbridge spillway whilst this level exceeds 7.45m. 

The drain level at Currymoor pumping station is 6.06 m and falling by approximately 10mm per hour. Cutts Road floods when this level is above 5.75m, and New Road when the level is above 6.18m. There is a risk of water overtopping Haymoor flood storage area and affecting Curload and Stan Moor if this level reaches 8.30m.

Be aware that Cutts Road is closed. Please refer to www.somerset.gov.uk/roads-travel-and-parking/emergency-road-closure-gates for more information.

Weather conditions are forecast to remain largely dry for the next few days.

We are currently pumping at both Northmoor and Currymoor pumping stations, and will continue to clear water from the moors as river levels allow. We are continually monitoring the situation, and staff are checking the condition of flood banks, spillways and weed screens. 

This message will be updated by 2 PM on 23/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Severn in Worcestershire
items.message:
River levels are falling but remain high as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland remains possible. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent the river from Highley to Tewkesbury. Locations affected are Stourport, Holt Fleet, Worcester, Kempsey, Severn Stoke and Upton upon Severn. Install property level protection if required. 

Peaks:- Bewdley 4.2m overnight Saturday, 19/10/2024, Worcester 5.08m Sunday afternoon 20/10/2024, Diglis 4.72m Sunday afternoon 20/10/2024, Kempsey Yacht Club 6.82m Sunday afternoon, 20/10/2024, and Saxons Lode 5.03m, Sunday evening 20/10/2024. 

No further significant rainfall is forecast. River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.
  
This message will be updated by 9am on Thursday 24/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
River levels remain high at the Haw Bridge river gauge as a result of high tides coinciding with rising river levels from recent heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland remains possible, with levels increasing during the high tides. We expect flooding to affect Gabb Lane at Apperley and local caravan parks.

Peak at Haw Bridge: 4.99m on Sunday evening, 20/10/2024.   

Tidal peaks are beginning to recede. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

This message will be updated by 9am on Thursday 24/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the West of Dorset
items.message:
Groundwater levels have risen in response to recent rainfall. Levels are expected to remain high and flooding of fields and roads is possible. Levels are reactive to further rainfall. No further rainfall is expected over the next few days.

Flooding of roads and fields is possible. Where groundwater is near the surface, intense rainfall will lead to surface water flooding.

Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. We will continue to monitor the situation closely.

This message will be updated by 16:00 PM on 29/10/2024.

items.description: River Ebble and tributaries
items.message:
Rising river levels this afternoon may lead to flooding.
Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible, property flooding is not expected.
Flooding is possible from 15:00 PM on 22/10/2024.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Ebble, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Alvediston and Nunton.
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels 
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses.
Please do not drive through floodwater as bow waves may affect adjacent properties.
Stay away from floodwater - it contains hidden dangers such as open manhole covers, sewage and chemicals.
This message will be updated by 3:00 PM on 23/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message:
River and lake levels are steadily falling but remain high. Flooding of low lying land and roads is possible. 

Flooding is possible near the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around The Upper Derwent from Seathwaite to Derwent Water. 

Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. 

This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 24/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Cranborne Chase area
items.message:
Groundwater levels have risen in response to recent rainfall. Levels are expected to continue to rise and flooding of fields and roads is possible. Levels are reactive to further rainfall. No rainfall is expected over the next few days.

Flooding of roads and fields is possible. Where groundwater is near the surface, intense rainfall will lead to surface water flooding.

Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. We will continue to monitor the situation closely.

This message will be updated by 16:00 PM on 29/10/2024.
